reviews.author: The_Unknown
reviews.title: Easy grades
reviews.comment_content:
Although there were  many lecture slides, I guess the content can be summarized into:
1. Culture
2. Deviance
3. Modern life
4. Family and intimate relationships
reviews.comment_teaching: I think the teaching was good and the class was pretty interactive. There were numerous extra materials and videos to supplement lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
As long as you attend lectures, you can get good grade. I think classroom participation is important if you want good grades.

Midterm: 37/40 (Mean 28.15/40)
Assignment: 10/10 (Mean 9.41/10)
Final Exam: 37/46 (Mean 33.46/46)

Final grade: A

Even if you do finals badly, as long as you actively participate in class and have other sections good, it should be fine.
reviews.comment_workload: Very low workload. Only one written assignment of around 500-600 words. As long as you spend a few hours researching, you can easily complete it.

reviews.author: JYY
reviews.title: Interesting course with easy grades
reviews.comment_content:
Simple topics that gives a good introduction to sociology. Since this year was online, professor couldn't go through all the topics he wanted to cover.
Topics:
Part I: Culture
Part II: Deviance
Part III: Modernization and Social Structure

I found the course content mostly interesting and it wasn't difficult at all as we didn't go in-depth about these topics. Make sure you get the textbook (can find for free from UST online library).
reviews.comment_teaching: Professor seems very passionate about sociology and does a good job managing a huge class. He also always makes the important takeaways very clear each lecture, and will also provide a summary of the previous lectures so that students know what key information that should have gotten out of each lecture.
reviews.comment_grading:
Grading:
- Midterm: 25% (Mostly MC, 2 short answers, 45 min)
No. of students: 387
Mean 70.38 (out of 100)
Median 70 (out of 100)      
SD 14.58 (out of 100)  

- Final: 40% (Mostly MC questions, 1 short answer, 50 min)
No. of students: 387
Mean 72.82 (out of 100)
Median 73.91 (out of 100)
SD 13.46 (out of 100)

- Attendance: 10%
I think they allow up to 3 absences before they start taking points off. You also have to turn on camera throughout each lecture.

- Participation: 5%
- Written Assignment: 20%
Mean = 9.41, SD = 0.57

My scores for reference:
Midterm: 37/40
Final: 43/46
Written Assignment: 10/10
Final Grade: A
reviews.comment_workload:
Only one written assignment that was really easy, and the rest of the course workload is the assigned reading which shouldn't be difficult as the professor will go over each reading in class and point out the main takeaways for each reading.
Only problem is that attendance is necessary for the 10% grade, so you can't miss too many lectures.

reviews.author: Fickdeinemutter
reviews.title: Don't Know Why I Took This
reviews.comment_content:
- Culture and Socialization
- Deviance
- Family and Gender
- Class inequalities
- Education
- Power and Politics

Stupid sociology's stuff. Unfalsifiable theories followed by unfalsifiable theories. Utter gibberish!
reviews.comment_teaching: I don't know her character, but the teaching is mediocre. I would not say boring, but I find difficult giving her good appraisal. She was awarded something like Best Teaching Award last year, which I don't know why this is possible.
reviews.comment_grading:
I got 1.4 SD below mean in the Mid-Term, 0.6 SD below mean in the Final Exam & don't know the score of my essay. BOTH Mid-Term & Final Exam consisted of ONLY MC.

Also three bonus points in maximum for in-class submissions (essay-type questions) following video-playing by her.

I was given a C+. I consider it as fair.

I would not recommend this course to those who just want to fulfill the CC / Free Elective requirements.
reviews.comment_workload:
Too many required readings. Too much time would be wasted on revision if you aim for a good grade.

I would not recommend this course to those who just want to fulfill the CC / Free Elective requirements.
